newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korea's Hansol Group expected to survive scandal.
newsitem.headline: S.Korea's Hansol Group expected to survive scandal.

text.p: The business operations of South Korea's Hansol Group are expected to emerge unscathed from the firm's alleged connection to a sleaze scandal surrounding the son of President Kim Young-sam, analysts said on Thursday.
"There's no doubt the scandal will hurt Hansol's image," said Suh Boyun, head of research at Dongsuh Securities. "But the group's business activities will not be affected."
Hansol, whose flagship firm Hansol Paper is South Korea's largest paper-maker, is the country's 16th-largest business conglomerate.

By late on Thursday, prosecutors had not confirmed local media reports they had evidence that Hansol had managed a seven billion won ($7.8 million) fund at the request of an associate of the president's son, Kim Hyun-chul.
The main opposition National Congress for New Politics alleged the money was part of a 20 billion won fund left over from President Kim's 1992 election campaign.
Prosecution officials have said an arrest warrant will be sought against the younger Kim soon.
But the issue is not seen creating long-term damage to Hansol in a country with a long history of forgiving transgressions committed by business figures.

"I do not expect a big impact on the Hansol Group, as the scandal is unlikely to develop into anything that pressures the group," said Chung Dong-bae, head of investment information at Daewoo Securities.

Kim Woo-choong, the globe-trotting chairman of the third-ranked Daewoo Group, and the chairmen of the Dong-Ah and Jinro groups all walked free despite convictions last year for bribing former president Roh Tae-woo.
The tycoons received suspended sentences. Their conglomerates were spared punishment altogether.
"What happens in Korea is a personal reckoning rather than a corporate reckoning," said Henry Morris, managing director of securities firm Coryo International (H.K.) Ltd.
"If the Hansol investigation results in a court proceeding, it will be against people, not the Hansol companies."

Share prices of Hansol's seven listed firms took a beating on Wednesday, with Hansol Paper and Hansol Electron going limit-down. The drubbing continued on Thursday morning, but by the end of the day a recovery had begun.
At the close of trading, five of the seven companies, including Hansol Paper and Hansol Electron, were unchanged from Wednesday's close of 19,600 won and 22,400 won, respectively.
Hansol Merchant Bank fell 200 won to 8,600, and Hansol Chemical Co Ltd rose 400 won to 23,300.
The Korea Composite Stock Price Index fell 4.41 points, or 0.64 percent, to 684.69.
"Once the shock and disappointment wears off, people start to look at the situation more rationally," Morris said. "Hansol is very well-regarded."
Analysts praised the group's expansion into non-paper businesses such as telecommunications and merchant banking.

"The group is heading in the right direction by expanding into future-oriented areas including information technology," said Suh of Dongsuh Securities. "Hansol has good cash flow and it has utilised the stock market well to raise money."
Hansol was spun off from the giant Samsung Group several years ago. The group is controlled by the sister of Samsung chairman Lee Kun-hee. ($1 = 895 won)
